description: From Middle English wormwode, a folk etymology (as if worm +‎ wood) of wermode (“wormwood”), from Old English wermōd, wormōd (“wormwood, absinthe”), from Proto-West Germanic *warjamōdā (“wormwood”). Cognate with Middle Low German wermode, wermede (“wormwood”), German Wermut (“wormwood”). Doublet of vermouth.

entries.meaning: An intensely bitter herb (Artemisia absinthium and similar plants in genus Artemisia) used in medicine, in the production of absinthe and vermouth, and as a tonic.
examples: Blue skippers in sunny hours ope and shut
Where wormwood and grunsel flowers by the cart ruts  […]

entries.meaning: (figurative) Something that causes bitterness or affliction; a cause of mortification or vexation.
examples: The irony of this reply was wormwood to Zeluco; he fell into a gloomy fit of musing, and made no farther inquiry  […] .
